revisions.rev:
The '''highest-valued currency unit''' is the [[currency]] in which a single unit buys the highest number of any given other currency or the largest amount of a given good. Most commonly the calculation is made against a major [[reserve currency]] such as the [[euro]] (EUR), the [[pound sterling]] (GBP) or the [[United States dollar]] (USD). A high-valued currency is distinct from a [[hard currency]], which is a currency with a good buying power and which is widely accepted as a reliable [[store of value]]. For example, a Kuwaiti dinar is not of very much use outside [[Kuwait]], and is bound to the [[Economy of Kuwait|economy of that country]]. It is in fact [[Fixed exchange rate|pegged]] to a basket of hard currencies. In contrast, the [[Japanese yen]] is considered a hard currency even though the nominal rate of the dinar is more than 280 timesAs of September 2011. Value taken from [http://www.xe.com www.xe.com]. that of the yen. == List of highest-valued currency units == As of October 9, 2011, the 13 highest-valued currencies are:Floating exchange rate data taken from [http://www.xe.com www.xe.com] on October 9, 2011, between 03:01 and 03:36 [[UTC]]. {|class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%; width: 100%" !
